awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing Online Laboratories for Computer Science Students to Learn How to Build Accessible Software and to Use Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by developing flexible online laboratories to help undergraduate computer science students learn important skills, including design of accessible software and use of artificial intelligence.  Specifically, the project aims to create, evaluate, and disseminate self-contained computer science laboratories about how to develop accessible software for individuals with cognitive impairments, hearing loss, vision impairment, and other disabilities. It also aims to create similar online laboratories to help computer science students learn about artificial intelligence/machine learning.  In design of the online labs, the project intends to develop a modular format that can identify beneficial features for both students and faculty across multiple topics. The labs will be based on real-world scenarios, will use an experiential learning model, and will address foundational topics from multiple angles. Including these increasingly essential topics in curricula can be challenging, especially for institutions with resource constraints.  The project’s online lab approach can help by providing learning resources that are self-contained and easily adoptable. In fact, adopting the labs will require only a web browser, and the project will provide instructors with supplemental materials such as lecture slides and instructional videos to help them successfully teach the topic. The project’s research efforts will focus on the design and dissemination of the online labs to better understand how to facilitate adoption at other institutions.  The research effort will also examine how inclusion of empathy-building content (in the accessibility labs) and ethics content (in the artificial intelligence labs) impact student users.  

This collaborative project from Rochester Institute of Technology and Bethune-Cookman University will develop ten self-contained labs for undergraduate computer science students: five addressing artificial intelligence/machine learning and five addressing the development of accessible software.   Beyond the development of these labs, major project goals include: (1) the development of a unified framework for self-contained labs that can be applied to other areas of computer science; (2) evaluation of the specific labs and the broader framework, considering both student users and faculty adopters; and (3) broad dissemination of the labs and the shared framework, including robust digital training opportunities.  The project’s mixed-methods research and evaluation plans will collect data from student focus groups and surveys and instructor interviews and assessments of student learning that will be compared to outcomes of students engaged in courses that use different, established mechanisms to teach similar content.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. This project is an Engaged Student Learning project through which the IUSE program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) supported this project to develop innovative online laboratories that equip computer science students with the skills to build accessible software and leverage artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies. This initiative represents a transformative approach to enhancing computer science education by integrating cutting-edge methodologies with a strong focus on accessibility and inclusivity.

Bethune-Cookman University collaborated on the development and testing of the laboratories. Over the award's lifetime, the project has significantly contributed to intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit

This project addressed critical gaps in computer science education by:

  1. Developing Advanced Online Laboratories: The project created and deployed online labs that simulate real-world programming environments, enabling students to learn and practice accessibility-focused software development and AI/ML applications. These labs incorporate tools for testing accessibility compliance and implementing AI algorithms, fostering hands-on learning experiences.
  2. Innovative Curriculum Design: The curriculum was designed to integrate universal design principles, accessibility standards, and ethical considerations in AI/ML. By embedding these elements into the computer science curriculum, the project ensured that students gain not only technical expertise but also a deep understanding of the societal implications of their work.
  3. Interdisciplinary Collaboration: The project brought together experts in computer science, accessibility, and education to create an interdisciplinary framework for teaching and learning. This collaboration resulted in adaptable resources for diverse educational settings and audiences.
  4. Research Contributions: The project generated significant research on effective methods for teaching accessibility and AI/ML in online environments. Findings could be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and workshops, contributing to the broader academic community.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this project have been far-reaching, addressing both educational equity and workforce readiness:

  1. Promoting Accessibility Awareness: By emphasizing accessibility in software development, the project raised awareness among future computer scientists about the importance of creating inclusive technologies. Students learned to design solutions that address the needs of diverse user groups, including individuals with disabilities.
  2. Expanding Access to Education: The online laboratories provided flexible learning opportunities, enabling students from underserved and underrepresented communities to access high-quality computer science education. This approach aligns with NSF’s commitment to broadening participation in STEM fields.
  3. Building Workforce Skills: The project equipped students with in-demand skills in AI/ML and accessible software development, preparing them for careers in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. Faculty and students participating in the program are better positioned to meet the needs of industries that prioritize inclusivity and ethical AI practices.
  4. Institutional Capacity Building: Participating institutions, including Bethune-Cookman University and other collaborators, enhanced their capacity to deliver cutting-edge computer science education. The resources and methodologies developed through this project will continue to benefit students and faculty beyond the award's life.
  5. Community Engagement: The project engaged with external stakeholders, including industry partners, advocacy groups, and educational organizations, to ensure the relevance and impact of its outcomes. These partnerships fostered knowledge exchange and helped bridge the gap between academia and practice.

Key Outcomes

  • Creation of Online Labs: The project developed a suite of online laboratories accessible to educators and students nationwide. (https://all.rit.edu/).
  • Enhanced Curriculum: The Computer Science and Computer Engineering Department at Bethune-Cookman University designed and implemented a comprehensive, accessibility-focused curriculum review. This review will collaborate with the Department of Software Engineering at Rochester Institute of Technology.
  • Increased Student Participation: Over 30 students from Bethune-Cookman University engaged with the online labs, with a significant proportion from underrepresented groups.
  • Research Publications: The project has not produced research papers that contribute to understanding effective online teaching strategies in computer science. The plans are to draft one or two manuscripts for publication.
  • Sustained Impact: The tools and resources developed continue to be used and adapted by educators and institutions, ensuring lasting benefits.

Conclusion

This project successfully demonstrated that integrating accessibility and AI/ML education into computer science curricula can produce well-rounded graduates prepared to tackle societal challenges. The innovative approaches and resources developed through this initiative have advanced computer science education and reinforced the importance of inclusivity and ethical considerations in technology. These contributions highlight the transformative potential of collaborative research in shaping a more equitable and accessible future.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2024
Modified by: Hector N Torres
